elements.content: Treatment of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 with excess Na or K metal in THF at room temperature gave closo-exo-[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]Na2(THF)4 (1) or [closo-exo-{(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10}K2(THF)2(O2C4H8)0.5] n (2) in good yield after recrystallization from a THF solution or a THF/dioxane solution, respectively. Dissolution of 2 in a THF solution of 18-crown-6 ether afforded an exo-nido-{K(18-crown-6)}{[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]K(18-crown-6)} (3). An equimolar reaction between 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 and K metal or 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 and [(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]K2 in THF at room temperature in the presence of 18-crown-6 ether generated two monoanion carborane compounds, [(THF)2K(18-crown-6)][nido-(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H11] (4) and {(THF)K(18-crown-6)}{1-(C6H5CH2)-2-(C6H5CH)-1,2-C2B10H10} (5), respectively. All of these complexes have been fully characterized by various spectroscopic data, elemental analyses, and X-ray diffraction studies. Compounds 1 − 3 represent the first structurally characterized examples of group 1 salts of carborane dianions of the C2B10 system.

All of these complexes have been fully characterized by various spectroscopic data, elemental analyses, and X-ray diffraction studies. elements.content: Group 1 metallacarboranes are not only very useful synthons for the production of various metallacarboranes of s-, p-, d-, and f-block elements, but they also have a rich structural and coordination chemistry of their own.
elements.clean_text: Group 1 metallacarboranes are not only very useful synthons for the production of various metallacarboranes of s-, p-, d-, and f-block elements, but they also have a rich structural and coordination chemistry of their own.

elements.content: It has been well-documented that o-C2B10H10R2 (R = H, alkyl, aryl) can be reduced by alkali metals to form M2[nido-C2B10H10R2], which is a very useful versatile synthon for the production of numerous metallacarboranes of s-, p-, d-, and f-elements. The structure and bonding between alkali metal ion and [nido-C2B10H10R2]2- have, however, remained largely unexplored although many attempts had been made. For a recent example, biscarborane (C2B10H11)2 was reduced by two electrons in the hope that this reaction would result in the formation of a species that contained one carborane cage opened by the reduction and analogous to the [nido-C2B10H12]2- anion, while the second closo cage would serve solely as an ancillary group. In fact, a biscarborane ion, [(C2B10H11)2]2-, with one negative charge on each carborane cage was isolated. These problems also interest theoreticians. The molecular structures of [C2B10H12]2- and the related species were proposed on the basis of theoretical calculations, and these results were recently reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

It has been well-documented that o-C2B10H10R2 (R = H, alkyl, aryl) can be reduced by alkali metals to form M2[nido-C2B10H10R2], which is a very useful versatile synthon for the production of numerous metallacarboranes of s-, p-, d-, and f-elements. The structure and bonding between alkali metal ion and [nido-C2B10H10R2]2- have, however, remained largely unexplored although many attempts had been made. For a recent example, biscarborane (C2B10H11)2 was reduced by two electrons in the hope that this reaction would result in the formation of a species that contained one carborane cage opened by the reduction and analogous to the [nido-C2B10H12]2- anion, while the second closo cage would serve solely as an ancillary group. In fact, a biscarborane ion, [(C2B10H11)2]2-, with one negative charge on each carborane cage was isolated. These problems also interest theoreticians. The molecular structures of [C2B10H12]2- and the related species were proposed on the basis of theoretical calculations, and these results were recently reported in the literature.

elements.content: We have recently reported that o-C2B10H10R2 can be reduced to [arachno-C2B10H10R2]4- by excess alkali metal in the presence of UCl4, YCl3, or lanthanide chlorides. In contrast, treatment of o-C2B10H10R2 with excess alkali metal gives only [nido-C2B10H10R2]2- in the absence of transition metal halides.

In contrast, treatment of o-C2B10H10R2 with excess alkali metal gives only [nido-C2B10H10R2]2- in the absence of transition metal halides.

elements.content: In view of the above-mentioned problems and rich coordination chemistry of main group metallacarboranes of C2B4 system, we have become interested in exploring the chemistry of group 1 metallacarboranes of the C2B10 system. We report herein the syntheses and structural characterization of several closo-exo, exo-nido, and pseudocloso group 1 metallacarboranes of 1,2-(CH2C6H5)2-1,2-C2B10H10. Effects of coordinating solvents on the molecular structures of metallacarboranes are also discussed in this paper.

We report herein the syntheses and structural characterization of several closo-exo, exo-nido, and pseudocloso group 1 metallacarboranes of 1,2-(CH2C6H5)2-1,2-C2B10H10. Effects of coordinating solvents on the molecular structures of metallacarboranes are also discussed in this paper.

elements.content: General Procedures. All experiments were preformed under an atmosphere of dry dinitrogen with the rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 was prepared according to the literature method. 18-Crown-6 ether was purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and purified according to the literature procedures. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received unless otherwise noted. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets prepared in the glovebox on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 Fourier transform spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47 MHz, respectively. 11B NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Inova 400 spectrometer at 128.32 MHz. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with references to the residual protons of the deuterated solvents for proton and carbon chemical shifts and to external BF3·OEt2 (0.00 ppm) for boron chemical shifts. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd., Brunel University, Middlesex, U.K.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 General Procedures. All experiments were preformed under an atmosphere of dry dinitrogen with the rigid exclusion of air and moisture using standard Schlenk or cannula techniques or in a glovebox. All organic solvents were freshly distilled from sodium benzophenone ketyl immediately prior to use. 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 was prepared according to the literature method. 18-Crown-6 ether was purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and purified according to the  literature procedures. All other chemicals were purchased from Aldrich Chemical Co. and used as received unless otherwise noted. Infrared spectra were obtained from KBr pellets prepared in the glovebox on a Perkin-Elmer 1600 Fourier transform spectrometer. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker DPX 300 spectrometer at 300.13 and 75.47 MHz, respectively. 11B NMR spectra were recorded on a Varian Inova 400 spectrometer at 128.32 MHz. All chemical shifts are reported in δ units with references to the residual protons of the deuterated solvents for proton and carbon chemical shifts and to external BF3⋅OEt2 (0.00 ppm) for boron chemical shifts. Elemental analyses were performed by MEDAC Ltd., Brunel University, Middlesex, U.K.

elements.content: Preparation of closo - exo -[(C 6 H 5 CH 2 ) 2 C 2 B 10 H 10 ]Na 2 (THF) 4 (1). To a solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.20 g, 0.62 mmol) in 15 mL of THF was added finely cut Na metal (0.11 g, 4.78 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. After removal of excess Na, the clear pale yellow solution was concentrated to about 8 mL. n-Hexane vapor diffusion at room temperature gave 1 as colorless crystals (0.21 g, 51%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 7.72 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, o-aryl H), 7.14 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, m-aryl H), 7.01 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, p-aryl H), 4.19 (s, 4H, C6H5CH 2), 3.64 (m, 16H, THF), 1.60 (m, 16H, THF). 13C NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 147.2, 129.1, 127.5, 124.3 (C 6H5CH2), 50.8 (C6H5 CH2), 67.2, 25.1 (THF); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −0.4 (4B), −6.7 (6B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3065 (w), 2969 (s), 2878 (s), 2506 (vs), 2422 (vs), 2350 (s), 1598 (w), 1489 (m), 1448 (m), 1243 (w), 1046 (s), 901 (m), 711 (m), 533 (w), 496 (w). Anal. Calcd for C28H48B10Na2O3 (1 − THF):  C, 57.31; H, 8.25. Found:  C, 57.55; H, 7.88.

elements.content: Preparation of {K(18-crown-6)}{ exo - nido -[(C 6 H 5 CH 2 ) 2 C 2 B 10 H 10 ]K(18-crown-6)} (3). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3050 (w), 3005 (w), 2886 (s), 2452 (s), 2393 (s), 2353 (s), 1597 (w), 1459 (m), 1350 (m), 1249 (m), 1107 (vs), 960 (s), 837 (w), 733 (w), 528 (w). Anal. elements.content: Preparation of [(THF)2K(18-crown-6)][ nido -(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H11] (4) and {(THF)K(18-crown-6)}{1-(C6H5CH2)-2-(C6H5CH)-1,2-C2B10H10} (5). To a solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.20 g, 0.62 mmol) in 15 mL of THF was added finely cut K metal (0.024 g, 0.62 mmol), and the mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 24 h until no K metal remained and a bright yellow solution resulted. No any gas evolution was detected. After addition of a toluene solution (20 mL) of 18-crown-6 ether (0.16 g, 0.61 mmol), the resulting solution was allowed to stand at 10 °C for 2 days, giving 4 as colorless crystals (0.14 g, 29%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 7.59 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, o-aryl H), 7.28 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H, m-aryl H), 7.17 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, p-aryl H), 4.26 (s, 4H, C6H5CH 2), 3.64 (m, 8H, THF), 3.41 (s, 24H, C12 H 24O6), 1.59 (m, 8H, THF). 13C NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 144.8, 129.0, 127.6, 124.8 (C 6H5CH2), 69.7 (C 12H24O6), 50.5 (C6H5 CH2), 67.1, 25.1 (THF); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 12.3 (1B), 4.5 (2B), −0.8 (1B), −8.4 (2B), −16.0 (2B), −19.6 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3066 (w), 3019 (w), 2956 (m), 2903 (s), 2521 (s), 2462 (m), 1601 (w), 1455 (m), 1350 (m), 1254 (m), 1106 (vs), 1056 (m), 959 (m), 902 (w), 803 (m), 729 (w), 516 (m). Anal. Calcd for C30H53B10KO6.5 (4 − 1.5THF):  C, 54.27; H, 7.89. Found:  C, 54.04; H, 8.25.

elements.content: Alternate Method. Finely cut K metal (0.13 g, 3.33 mmol) was added to a THF solution (10 mL) of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room-temperature overnight. Removal of excess K metal gave a pale yellow solution to which was then added a THF solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol) at room temperature. The color of the resulting solution was immediately turned to bright yellow, and this solution was then stirred at room temperature overnight. A toluene solution (20 mL) of 18-crown-6 ether (0.17 g, 0.64 mmol) was added. The resulting clear solution was stirred for 0.5 h, followed by the procedures used before affording 4 as colorless crystals (0.15 g, 32%) and 5 as bright yellow crystals (0.15 g, 35%), respectively.

elements.content: X-ray Structure Determination. All single crystals were immersed in Paraton-N oil and sealed under N2 in thin-walled glass capillaries. Data were collected at 293 K on an MSC/Rigaku RAXIS-IIC imaging plate using Mo Kα radiation from a Rigaku rotating-anode X-ray generator operating at 50 kV and 90 mA. An absorption correction was applied by correlation of symmetry-equivalent reflections using the ABSCOR program. All structures were solved by direct methods and subsequent Fourier difference techniques and refined anisotropically for all non-hydrogen atoms by full-matrix least squares calculations on F 2 using the Siemens SHELXTL program package (PC version). For noncentrosymmetric structures, the appropriate enantiomorph was chosen by refining Flack's parameter x toward zero. Most of the carborane hydrogen atoms were located from different Fourier syntheses. All other hydrogen atoms were geometrically fixed using the riding model. Crystal data and details of data collection and structure refinement are given in Table . Selected bond distances are listed in Table . Further details are included in the Supporting Information.

Dianion Compounds. Treatment of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 with excess finely cut Na metal in THF at room temperature gave, after recrystallization from a n-hexane/THF solution, a closo-exo-[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]Na2(THF)4 (1) as colorless crystals in 51% isolated yield. Its potassium analogue, under the same reaction condition, was isolated as a white powder. Recrystallization of this potassium salt from a mixed solvent of THF/dioxane/n-hexane afforded [closo-exo-{(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10}K2(THF)2(O2C4H8)0.5] n (2) as colorless crystals. Dissolution of 2 or the above powdered potassium salt in a THF solution of 18-crown-6 ether generated, after workup, {K(18-crown-6)}{exo-nido-[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]K(18-crown-6)} (3) as colorless crystals in 63% yield. All these transformations are summarized in Scheme .

elements.content: The 1H NMR spectra show that two benzyl groups on the carborane cage in all three compounds are equivalent in the solution and support the ratio of four THF molecules per carboranyl ligand for 1, two THF and a half dioxane molecules per ligand for 2, and two 18-crown-6 ether molecules per ligand for 3, respectively. The 13C NMR spectra are consistent with the results derived from the 1H NMR spectra. The 11B NMR spectra exhibit 2:3, 2:2:1, and 4:3:3 splitting patterns for 1 − 3, respectively, perhaps implying different structures for these compounds. Their solid-state IR spectra display both a characteristic doublet centered around 2460 cm-1 and a shoulder at about 2360 cm-1 attributable to a M−H−B stretching mode.

elements.content: The molecular structures of all three compounds have been confirmed by single-crystal X-ray analyses. As shown in Figure , compound 1 has a monomeric structure in which one sodium is bonded to the open six-membered C2B4 face in η6 fashion and the other is bonded to a trigonal B3 face through three B−H bonds forming a 13-vertex closo-exo-metallacarborane. The coordination sphere around the sodium atoms is then completed by four THF molecules.

elements.content: The Na(1)−cage atom distances range from 2.683(3) to 2.851(2) Å with an average value of 2.776(2) Å. This measured value compares to the 2.726(18) Å in [closo-exo-{(Me3Si)2C2B4H4}Na2(THF)4]2 and the value of 2.795 Å that would be expected by subtracting the difference, 0.12 Å, between Shannon's ionic radii of 7-coordinate and 9-coordinate sodium ions from the average Na−cage atom distance of 2.915(6) Å in closo-exo-[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]4Sm2Na3. The average Na(2)···B (B3 face) distance of 2.850(2) Å is close to the 2.845(19) Å in [closo-exo-{(Me3Si)2C2B4H4}Na2(THF)4]2 17 and the 2.892 Å derived from the subtraction of the difference in the ionic radii, 0.12 Å, from the average Na···B (B3 face) distance, 3.012(6) Å, in closo-exo-[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]4Sm2Na3 19 and is also comparable to the corresponding values found in the literature. The distances between the benzyl substituents and Na(1) range from 2.998(2) to 4.383(2) Å with the closest approach being through C(22), implying that the Na(1) ion has certain interactions with the aromatic rings.

elements.content: In contrast to compound 1, 2 adopts a polymeric structure in which the dioxane and the potassium ion serve as alternating bridging groups to give a zigzag metallacarborane−K−metallacarborane−dioxane−metallacarborane chain that is maintained in one-dimension throughout the lattice. As far as we are aware, 2 represents the first structurally characterized example of a metallacarborane of potassium element.

As far as we are aware, 2 represents the first structurally characterized example of a metallacarborane of potassium element.

elements.content: As shown in Figure , the K(1) ion is η6-bound to the hexagonal C2B4 face of the C2B10 cage forming a 13-vertex metallacarborane structural motif and coordinated to one oxygen atom of the bridging dioxane molecule, a coordination environment that is similar to that of Na(1) in 1. The distances from K(1) to the two phenyl rings of the benzyl substituents fall in a relatively large range (3.181(2)−3.657(2) Å), indicating a somewhat asymmetric K−arene interactions. The average K(1)−cage atom distance of 3.174(2) Å is close to the value of 3.116 Å that is expected by adding the difference, 0.34 Å, between Shannon's ionic radii18 of K+ and Na+ ions from the average Na−cage atom distance of 2.776(2) Å in 1 and the value of 3.18 Å derived from the subtraction of the difference in the ionic radii, 0.23 Å, from the average Cs−cage atom distance, 3.41(4) Å in [closo-exo-{(Me2Si)4C4B8H8}Cs2(TMEDA)] n . Another potassium ion K(2) in the solid-state structure of 2 is bonded to two trigonal B3 faces through two sets of three unequal K−H−B bonds from two neighboring carborane cages, and its coordinating sphere is completed by two THF molecules, as shown in Figure . The average K(2)···B distance of 3.253(2) Å is slightly longer than that of the K(1)−cage atom distance but is comparable to the 2.850(2) Å in 1 and the 3.64(4) Å in [closo-exo-{(Me2Si)4C4B8H8}Cs2(TMEDA)]n 23 if the differences in Shannon's ionic radii18 are taken into account.

elements.content: Unlike the molecular structures of 1 and 2, 3 consists of a nido-C2B10 cage and two K(18-crown-6) moieties, and they are linked to each other through a set of three unequal K(1)−H−B bonds and a K(2)−H−C bond, respectively, as shown in Figure . The average K(1)···B distance of 3.313(3) Å is close to the corresponding value of 3.253(2) Å in 2. Such interactions pull the K(1) atom out of the mean plane of six oxygen atoms of the crown ether molecule by 0.861 Å. In contrast, the K(2)···H(22)−C(21) interaction (3.00 Å) is relatively weak leading to a relatively small (0.338 Å) out of plane displacement for K(2). The average K(1)−O distance of 2.913(3) Å is longer than the 2.810(3) Å average K(2)−O distance due to the differences in coordination number and out of plane displacement of K+ ions. These measured values can be compared with those normally observed in the complexes containing the [K(18-crown-6)] moiety.

elements.content: Monoanion Compounds. Reaction of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 with 1 equiv of finely cut potassium metal in THF at room temperature gave, after addition of 18-crown-6 ether, [(THF)2K(18-crown-6)][nido-(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H11] (4) as colorless crystals in 29% yield and {(THF)K(18-crown-6)}{1-(C6H5CH2)-2-(C6H5CH)-1,2-C2B10H10} (5) as bright yellow crystals in 37% yield, respectively. Compounds 4 and 5 could also be prepared by mixing K2[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10] and 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 in a molar ratio of 1:1 in a THF solution of 18-crown-6 ether. These reactions are outlined in Scheme . Both compounds 4 and 5 are EPR-silent. 4 is air-stable, while 5 is air-sensitive. Traces of air convert 5 from bright yellow crystals to a colorless powder. They are soluble in THF and pyridine, sparingly soluble in toluene, and insoluble in n-hexane.

The IR spectrum of 4 exhibits a strong B−H absorption at 2521 cm-1 and a medium strong peak at 2462 cm-1, while that of 5 displays a strong sharp B−H absorption at 2533 cm-1. The 11B NMR spectra show 1:2:1:2:2:2 and 2:2:1:1:1:1:1:1 splitting patterns for 4 and 5, respectively. The 1H NMR spectrum of 4 shows one set of benzyl protons and supports the ratio of two THF and one 18-crown-6 ether molecules per carboranyl ligand, which is consistent with its 13C NMR results. The 1H NMR spectrum of 5, however, clearly exhibits two sets of aromatic protons and a singlet at δ = 7.05 ppm attributable to the vinyl proton, which is also reflected in the 13C NMR spectrum showing two sets of aromatic carbons and a unique resonance at δ = 118.9 ppm assignable to the vinyl carbon. The above-mentioned spectroscopic data suggest that 4 and 5 have different structures.

The 11B NMR spectra show 1:2:1:2:2:2 and 2:2:1:1:1:1:1:1 splitting patterns for 4 and 5, respectively. The 1H NMR spectrum of 4 shows one set of benzyl protons and supports the ratio of two THF and one 18-crown-6 ether molecules per carboranyl ligand, which is consistent with its 13C NMR results. The 1H NMR spectrum of 5, however, clearly exhibits two sets of aromatic protons and a singlet at δ = 7.05 ppm attributable to the vinyl proton, which is also reflected in the 13C NMR spectrum showing two sets of aromatic carbons and a unique resonance at δ = 118.9 ppm assignable to the vinyl carbon. The above-mentioned spectroscopic data suggest that 4 and 5 have different structures.

elements.content: An X-ray diffraction study reveals that 4 has an ionic structure consisting of well-separated, alternating layers of discrete cations [(THF)2K(18-crown-6)]+ and carborane monoanion [nido-(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H11]-. As shown in Figure , this monoanion contains a hexagonal face in which the four boron atoms are coplanar and the two carbon atoms are staggered, one above and one below this plane, a geometry that is similar to the kinetic product of [nido-(CH3)2C2B10H11]- 2 or the dianion [nido-(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]2- in 3 with the bridging proton removed. The less connected C(7) atom is 0.34 Å above the plane, and the more connected C(9) atom is 0.27 Å below the plane. The cation [(THF)2K(18-crown-6)]+ has crystallographically imposed C 2 symmetry and adopts a hexagonal-bipyramidal geometry with two THF molecules occupying the axial positions. The potassium ions are assigned half site occupancy and sit in the mean plane formed by six oxygen atoms of the 18-crown-6 ether molecule.

elements.content: The solid-state structure of 5 consists of a monoanion [1-(C6H5CH2)-2-(C6H5CH)-1,2-C2B10H10]- and a cation [(THF)K(18-crown-6)]+, which are associated with each other through a weak K···C(17) interaction at a distance of 3.211(3) Å that is very close to an average K···C interatomic distance of 3.210(7) Å observed in [K(18-crown-6)][{η 5-(Me3Si)2C5H3}2La(C6H6)], as shown in Figure . The carborane monoanion adopts a pseudocloso geometry in which the C(7)···C(12) connectivity is broken and an approximately square C(7)B(8)C(12)B(11) face is generated. Such geometry was also observed in the dianion [(C2B10H11)2]2-.

elements.content: The two long (C(12)−B(8,11) = 2.010(4), 1.847(3) Å) and two short (C(12)−B(9,10) = 1.617(3), 1.630(4) Å) C−B distances are observed in 5, which can be explained as being due to crystal packing forces. The C(12)−C(13) distance of 1.365(3) Å exhibits substantial double-bond character, which is very close to the C(cage)−C(cage) distance of 1.377(4) Å in [(C2B10H11)2]2-. It is further noted that the eight atoms of C(12) and C(13) to C(19) are coplanar, indicating that the negative charge is delocalized over the cage and one of the two benzyl groups, which can stabilize the monoanion, and on the other hand can explain the interaction between K(1) and C(17). Close examinations show that the cage geometry in the present compound is very similar to that in [(C2B10H11)2]2-, which suggests that the function of the benzyl group in 5 resembles that of the carborane cage in [(C2B10H11)2]2-.

elements.content: Structural studies on compounds 1 − 3 reveal that the bonding between Na+ or K+ ion and carborane dianion is ionic in nature, and the capping alkali netal ion can be easily removed by strong chelating ligands such as 18-crown-6 ether or replaced by other main group and transition metal ions. These properties ensure M2[C2B10H10R2] to be useful synthons for the preparation of a variety of metallacarboranes. Since the interactions between M+ and carborane dianion are weak and the negative charge is localized on the cage, unlike transition metal analogues, group 1 metallacarboranes cannot be further reduced by group 1 metals although they have similar half-sandwich structures. Compounds 1 − 3 represent the first structurally characterized examples of group 1 metallacarboranes of the C2B10 system, which offer theoreticians experimental data for comparison.
elements.clean_text:
Discussion

Structural studies on compounds 1 - 3 reveal that the bonding between Na+ or K+ ion and carborane dianion is ionic in nature, and the capping alkali netal ion can be easily removed by strong chelating ligands such as 18-crown-6 ether or replaced by other main group and transition metal ions. These properties ensure M2[C2B10H10R2] to be useful synthons for the preparation of a variety of metallacarboranes. Since the interactions between M+ and carborane dianion are weak and the negative charge is localized on the cage, unlike transition metal analogues, group 1 metallacarboranes cannot be further reduced by group 1 metals although they have similar half-sandwich structures. Compounds 1 - 3 represent the first structurally characterized examples of group 1 metallacarboranes of the C2B10 system, which offer theoreticians experimental data for comparison.

elements.content: The formation of compounds 4 and 5 is very interesting. To gain some insight into the reduction reaction, alternate methods were approached, and 11B NMR was employed to follow these reactions. Since compounds 4 and 5 can be isolated from either treatment of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 with 1 equiv of K metal or reaction of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 with K2[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10] in a molar ratio of 1:1 in the presence of 18-crown-6 ether, one-electron reduction of carborane cage could then be ruled out. In the former reaction, a half amount of the carborane cage is reduced by K metal to give K2[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10] that then reacts with the remaining half amount of carborane to form an unknown species. The 11B NMR spectrum of this species exhibits only two resonances at 9.6 and 3.9 ppm in a ratio of 3:7, a splitting pattern which differs from that of neutral carborane, carborane dianion, and compounds 4 and 5. Many attempts were made without success to isolate this species. Upon addition of 18-crown-6 ether, many resonances appeared in the 11B NMR which are attributable to both 4 and 5. From this solution, 4 and 5 were isolated as final products in reasonable yields.

The 11B NMR spectrum of this species exhibits only two resonances at 9.6 and 3.9 ppm in a ratio of 3:7, a splitting pattern which differs from that of neutral carborane, carborane dianion, and compounds 4 and 5. Many attempts were made without success to isolate this species. Upon addition of 18-crown-6 ether, many resonances appeared in the 11B NMR which are attributable to both 4 and 5. From this solution, 4 and 5 were isolated as final products in reasonable yields.

elements.content: It has been known that [nido-C2B10H10R2]2- is a Lewis base (6e- donor) and the methylene proton of the benzyl group in 1-CH3-2-(C6H5CH2)-1,2-C2B10H10 is a weak Brønsted acid with pK a = 19.5. An acid−base adduct may be formed in a THF solution upon mixing [(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]K2 with 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10. Addition of 18-crown-6 ether will remove the capping K+ ion leaving a “naked” open hexagonal C2B4 face bearing three pairs of electrons, which could enhance the Lewis basicity of the carborane dianion; this anion may then attack the acidic proton of the benzyl group of neutral carborane molecule resulting in the formation of the monoanions 4 and 5 (Scheme ). 4 is a kinetic product of the monoprotonated dianion and will slowly isomerize to a more stable thermodynamic species at room temperature over a period of 1 week as evidenced by the 11B NMR. The above hypothesis for the formation of 5 is further supported by the following experiment. Treatment of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 with 1 equiv of n-BuLi in THF in the presence of 18-crown-6 ether gave a species that has a 11B NMR spectrum identical with that of 5. It is proposed that n-BuLi deprotonates one of the methylene hydrogens of a benzyl group in 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 to generate a carbanionic center immediately adjacent to the carborane icosahedron, and the anionic charge delocalizes into the electron-deficient cage by forming an exo double bond. A similar phenomenon was observed in the anions [1-X-2-C6H5-1,2-C2B10H10]- (X = O, S, NR).

elements.content: Group 1 metallacarboranes of C2B10 system have been structurally characterized for the first time. Their structures are very diverse, ranging from monomeric to polymeric and from closo through psedocloso to nido structures depending on the chelating solvents and negative charge on the carborane cage.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Group 1 metallacarboranes of C2B10 system have been structurally characterized for the first time. Their structures are very diverse, ranging from monomeric to polymeric and from closo through psedocloso to nido structures depending on the chelating solvents and negative charge on the carborane cage.

elements.content: The bonding interactions between group 1 metal ion and carborane dianion are relatively weak and ionic in nature, so that the capping metal ion in 13-vertex metallacarboranes can be easily removed by strong chelating ligands such as 18-crown-6 ether or replaced by transition metal ions, which ensures group 1 metallacarboranes to be very useful synthons for the production of various metallacarboranes. Such weak interactions lead to the localization of the negative charge on the carborane cage, which prevents further reduction of 13-vertex group 1 metallacarboranes by alkali metals. In contrast, 13-vertex metallacarboranes of transition metals can be further reduced by alkali metals to form a new type of metallacarborane.

Such weak interactions lead to the localization of the negative charge on the carborane cage, which prevents further reduction of 13-vertex group 1 metallacarboranes by alkali metals. In contrast, 13-vertex metallacarboranes of transition metals can be further reduced by alkali metals to form a new type of metallacarborane.

elements.content: An unprecedented proton-transfer reaction between the dianion [nido-(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10]2- and neutral carborane 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 is discovered, which leads to the isolation and structurally characterization of two monoanion carborane compounds. The possible pathways for the formation of these compounds are also proposed.

The possible pathways for the formation of these compounds are also proposed.

Preparation of closo - exo -[(C 6 H 5 CH 2 ) 2 C 2 B 10 H 10 ]Na 2 (THF) 4 (1). To a solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.20 g, 0.62 mmol) in 15 mL of THF was added finely cut Na metal (0.11 g, 4.78 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room temperature overnight. After removal of excess Na, the clear pale yellow solution was concentrated to about 8 mL. n-Hexane vapor diffusion at room temperature gave 1 as colorless crystals (0.21 g, 51%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 7.72 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, o-aryl H), 7.14 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, m-aryl H), 7.01 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, p-aryl H), 4.19 (s, 4H, C6H5CH 2), 3.64 (m, 16H, THF), 1.60 (m, 16H, THF). 13C NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 147.2, 129.1, 127.5, 124.3 (C 6H5CH2), 50.8 (C6H5 CH2), 67.2, 25.1 (THF); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −0.4 (4B), −6.7 (6B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3065 (w), 2969 (s), 2878 (s), 2506 (vs), 2422 (vs), 2350 (s), 1598 (w), 1489 (m), 1448 (m), 1243 (w), 1046 (s), 901 (m), 711 (m), 533 (w), 496 (w). Anal. Calcd for C28H48B10Na2O3 (1 − THF):  C, 57.31; H, 8.25. Found:  C, 57.55; H, 7.88.

Preparation of [ closo - exo -{(C 6 H 5 CH 2 ) 2 C 2 B 10 H 10 }K 2 (THF) 2 (O 2 C 4 H 8 ) 0.5 ] n (2). A finely cut K metal (0.13 g, 3.33 mmol) was added to a solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.20 g, 0.62 mmol) in 15 mL of THF, and the mixture was stirred at room-temperature overnight. Removal of excess K metal, addition of a few drops of dioxane, and n-hexane vapor diffusion afforded 2 as colorless crystals (0.25 g, 68%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 7.74 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, o-aryl H), 7.27 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 4H, m-aryl H), 7.12 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, p-aryl H), 4.07 (s, 4H, C6H5CH 2), 3.66 (m, 8H, THF), 3.62 (s, 4H, dioxane), 1.62 (m, 8H, THF). 13C NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 146.7, 129.0, 128.1, 124.8 (C 6H5CH2), 67.2, 25.2 (THF), 66.5 (dioxane), 51.1 (C6H5 CH2); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −3.3 (4B), −5.4 (4B), −25.5 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3066 (w), 2965 (m), 2915 (s), 2862 (s), 2506 (vs), 2447 (vs), 2391 (s), 1595 (w), 1487 (m), 1447 (m), 1253 (m), 1113 (s), 1049 (vs), 878 (m), 712 (m), 616 (w), 538 (w), 496 (w). Anal. Calcd for C22H36B10K2O2 (2 − THF):  C, 50.92; H, 6.99. Found:  C, 51.31; H, 6.97.

Preparation of {K(18-crown-6)}{ exo - nido -[(C 6 H 5 CH 2 ) 2 C 2 B 10 H 10 ]K(18-crown-6)} (3). To a THF solution of K2[(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H10] (15 mL, 0.62 mmol) was added a THF solution (5 mL) of 18-crown-6 ether (0.17 g, 0.64 mmol) at room temperature, and the mixture was stirred for 30 min. After concentration of the resulting clear pale yellow solution to about 10 mL, toluene (about 8 mL) was added. 3 was isolated as colorless crystals after this solution stood at room temperature overnight (0.36 g, 63%).1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 7.96 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, o-aryl H), 7.23 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H, m-aryl H), 7.08 (t, J = 6.9 Hz, 2H, p-aryl H), 4.38 (s, 4H, C6H5CH 2), 3.40 (s, 48H, C12 H 24O6). 13C NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 130.2, 127.0 (C 6H5CH2), 69.9 (C 12H24O6), 51.0 (C6H5 CH2); other carbon atoms were not observed. 11B NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ −7.2 (4B), −18.8 (3B), −25.1 (3B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3050 (w), 3005 (w), 2886 (s), 2452 (s), 2393 (s), 2353 (s), 1597 (w), 1459 (m), 1350 (m), 1249 (m), 1107 (vs), 960 (s), 837 (w), 733 (w), 528 (w). Anal. Calcd for C40H72B10K2O12:  C, 51.59; H, 7.79. Found:  C, 51.83; H, 7.55.

Preparation of [(THF)2K(18-crown-6)][ nido -(C6H5CH2)2C2B10H11] (4) and {(THF)K(18-crown-6)}{1-(C6H5CH2)-2-(C6H5CH)-1,2-C2B10H10} (5). To a solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.20 g, 0.62 mmol) in 15 mL of THF was added finely cut K metal (0.024 g, 0.62 mmol), and the mixture was then stirred at room temperature for 24 h until no K metal remained and a bright yellow solution resulted. No any gas evolution was detected. After addition of a toluene solution (20 mL) of 18-crown-6 ether (0.16 g, 0.61 mmol), the resulting solution was allowed to stand at 10 °C for 2 days, giving 4 as colorless crystals (0.14 g, 29%). 1H NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 7.59 (d, J = 7.2 Hz, 4H, o-aryl H), 7.28 (t, J = 7.5 Hz, 4H, m-aryl H), 7.17 (t, J = 7.2 Hz, 2H, p-aryl H), 4.26 (s, 4H, C6H5CH 2), 3.64 (m, 8H, THF), 3.41 (s, 24H, C12 H 24O6), 1.59 (m, 8H, THF). 13C NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 144.8, 129.0, 127.6, 124.8 (C 6H5CH2), 69.7 (C 12H24O6), 50.5 (C6H5 CH2), 67.1, 25.1 (THF); the carbon atoms of the cage were not observed. 11B NMR (pyridine-d 5):  δ 12.3 (1B), 4.5 (2B), −0.8 (1B), −8.4 (2B), −16.0 (2B), −19.6 (2B). IR (KBr, cm-1):  ν 3066 (w), 3019 (w), 2956 (m), 2903 (s), 2521 (s), 2462 (m), 1601 (w), 1455 (m), 1350 (m), 1254 (m), 1106 (vs), 1056 (m), 959 (m), 902 (w), 803 (m), 729 (w), 516 (m). Anal. Calcd for C30H53B10KO6.5 (4 − 1.5THF):  C, 54.27; H, 7.89. Found:  C, 54.04; H, 8.25.

Alternate Method. Finely cut K metal (0.13 g, 3.33 mmol) was added to a THF solution (10 mL) of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room-temperature overnight. Removal of excess K metal gave a pale yellow solution to which was then added a THF solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol) at room temperature. The color of the resulting solution was immediately turned to bright yellow, and this solution was then stirred at room temperature overnight. A toluene solution (20 mL) of 18-crown-6 ether (0.17 g, 0.64 mmol) was added. The resulting clear solution was stirred for 0.5 h, followed by the procedures used before affording 4 as colorless crystals (0.15 g, 32%) and 5 as bright yellow crystals (0.15 g, 35%), respectively.

No any gas evolution was detected. Finely cut K metal (0.13 g, 3.33 mmol) was added to a THF solution (10 mL) of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol), and the mixture was stirred at room-temperature overnight. Removal of excess K metal gave a pale yellow solution to which was then added a THF solution of 1,2-(C6H5CH2)2-1,2-C2B10H10 (0.10 g, 0.31 mmol) at room temperature. The color of the resulting solution was immediately turned to bright yellow, and this solution was then stirred at room temperature overnight. A toluene solution (20 mL) of 18-crown-6 ether (0.17 g, 0.64 mmol) was added. The resulting clear solution was stirred for 0.5 h, followed by the procedures used before affording 4 as colorless crystals (0.15 g, 32%) and 5 as bright yellow crystals (0.15 g, 35%), respectively.
